papers.abstract: Accessibility efforts, how we can make the world usable and useful to as many people as possible, have focused on how we can support and allow for the autonomy and independence of people with disabilities, neurodivergencies, chronic conditions, and older adults. Despite these efforts, not all technology is designed or implemented to support everyone's needs. TikTok. Recently, a community-organized push by creators and general users of TikTok urged the platform to add accessibility features, such as closed captioning, to allow more people to use the platform with greater ease. Through an interview study exploring the experiences of creatives on TikTok, we explore the creative practices of people with ADHD and those who experience similar challenges, focusing on the kinds of accessibility they create through their creative work. We find that creatives engage in critical infrastructuring–a process of bottom-up (re)design–to make the platform more accessible despite the challenges the platform presents to them as creators through creating and augmenting video editing and video captioning infrastructures. We then reflect on how the introduction of a top-down infrastructure - the implementation of an auto-captioning feature - shifts the critical infrastructure practices of TikTok creatives. Through their infrastructuring, creatives were revising the broader sociotechnical capabilities of TikTok to support their own needs as well as the broader needs of the TikTok community. We discuss how the routine of infrastructuring accessibility is a form of incidental care work and highlight how accessibility is an evolving sociotechnical construct, forwarding the concept of contextual accessibility.

events.Text: Accessibility efforts, how we can make the world usable and useful to as many people as possible, have focused on how we can support and allow for the autonomy and independence of people with disabilities, neurodivergencies, chronic conditions, and older adults. Despite these efforts, not all technology is designed or implemented to support everyone's needs. TikTok. Recently, a community-organized push by creators and general users of TikTok urged the platform to add accessibility features, such as closed captioning, to allow more people to use the platform with greater ease.
events.Main Action: a community-organized push by creators and general users of TikTok urged the platform

Agent: community-organized push by creators and general users of TikTok

Secondary Object: accessibility features such as closed captions

Context: Despite these efforts, not all technology is designed or implemented to support everyone's needs.
a recently emerged community-organized push by creators and general users of TikTok urged the platform
Purpose: to urge the platform to add accessibility features.
Method: collaboration between active users and creators working together towards a common goal—to influence TikTok's feature development process.
Results: the call for inclusion led to successful addition of necessary features.
Challenge: challenges associated with this event probably involve coordinating large-scale changes effectively.
Ethical: ethical concerns, justifications or implications of the event

events.Text: Through an interview study exploring the experiences of creatives on TikTok, we explore the creative practices of people with ADHD and those who experience similar challenges, focusing on the kinds of accessibility they create through their creative work.

Secondary Object: creative practices involving people with ADHD

events.Text: We find that creatives engage in critical infrastructuring–a process of bottom-up (re)design–to make the platform more accessible despite the challenges the platform presents to them as creators through creating and augmenting video editing and video captioning infrastructures. We then reflect on how the introduction of a top-down infrastructure - the implementation of an auto-captioning feature - shifts the critical infrastructure practices of TikTok creatives. Through their infrastructuring, creatives were revising the broader sociotechnical capabilities of TikTok to support their own needs as well as the broader needs of the TikTok community.

Primary Object: video editing and video captioning infrastructures

Context: challenges the platform presents to them as creators
Results: ability to revise broader societal capabilities supporting themselves and others
Analysis: processes of re-design affecting wider aspects of technology
Implications: broader impact on digital media creation and consumption

events.Text: We discuss how the routine of infrastructuring accessibility is a form of incidental care work and highlight how accessibility is an evolving sociotechnical construct, forwarding the concept of contextual accessibility.

Context: We discuss how the routine of infrastructuring accessibility is a form of incidental care work
and highlight how accessibility is an evolving sociotechnical construct
Purpose: highlighting how accessibility is an evolving sociotechnical construct
forwarding the concept of contextual accessibility
Implications: This study proposes a new way of understanding accessibility
which could lead to further explorations of how different contexts influence accessibility definitions and measures across various settings.

papers.abstract: Current cultural policies are evolving from social inclusion (removing barriers and promoting equality for participation in culture) to social cohesion (fostering solid bonds between groups despite their differences). Digital interventions can create spaces that promote social inclusion and cohesion. In this paper, we report on the design and evaluation of a cultural heritage and digital storytelling application supporting a participatory approach to culture and hosting society. We evaluate our intervention in three marginalized communities with different social-cultural contexts: migrant women in Barcelona, a community living in a priority neighbourhood in Paris, and second and third-generation migrants in Lisbon. Through an analysis of their application use, our findings point at their needs and desires, highlighting how the app can support social inclusion as the first step towards cohesion, but that these are heterogeneous concepts susceptible to nuanced appropriations by the different communities.

events.Text: Current cultural policies are evolving from social inclusion (removing barriers and promoting equality for participation in culture) to social cohesion (fostering solid bonds between groups despite their differences). Digital interventions can create spaces that promote social inclusion and cohesion.

In this paper, we report on the design and evaluation of a cultural heritage and digital storytelling application supporting a participatory approach to culture and hosting society. We evaluate our intervention in three marginalized communities with different social-cultural contexts: migrant women in Barcelona, a community living in a priority neighbourhood in Paris, and second and third-generation migrants in Lisbon.

Through an analysis of their application use, our findings point at their needs and desires, highlighting how the app can support social inclusion as the first step towards cohesion, but that these are heterogeneous concepts susceptible to nuanced appropriations by the different communities.

Secondary Object: how the app can support social inclusion as the first step towards cohesion

Context: Our findings point at their needs and desires
Purpose: to explore how users interacted with apps concerning social aspects
Results: Our findings point at their needs and desires
Analysis: highlighting how the app can support social inclusion as the first step towards cohesion, but that these are heterogeneous concepts susceptible to nuances appropriated by the different communities.
Implications: These findings imply that addressing social inclusion requires understanding the unique ways different communities interpret and respond to technological interventions.
